channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: As Zelensky Calls for Speedy Tank Deliveries, Timing Remains Key Question
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine has asked allies to quickly supply pledged armaments and ‘new necessary weaponry,’ but getting promised tanks will take time, as will training for Ukrainian troops.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times

item.title: Baghdad Loses Green Space to Real Estate Boom
item.description: The problem is driving up temperatures in what is already one of the hottest cities in the world, where air-conditioning is a luxury only the rich can afford.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf, Yasmine Mosimann and Emily Garthwaite
item.media:credit: Emily Garthwaite for The New York Times

item.title: Blinken Meets Netanyahu at Turbulent Moment for Israel
item.description: The secretary of state and the Israeli leader had a ‘candid’ conversation amid deepening rifts over the Palestinians, Ukraine and a rightward shift by Benjamin Netanyahu’s government.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel arriving for a joint news conference in Jerusalem on Monday.

item.title: The Double Whammy Making Italy the West’s Fastest Shrinking Nation
item.description: Italy’s population of elder Italians is soaring as its birthrate plummets, putting the country at the forefront of a global demographic trend that experts call the “silver tsunami.”
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Elisabetta Zavoli for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Elderly and Children Together project in Piacenza, Italy, in December.

item.title: Golf Course or Housing? A Patch of Green Divides Hong Kong
item.description: The dispute over one of the city’s golf clubs exposes rare political friction for the elite in the new Hong Kong, where the establishment is torn between defending wealth and following Beijing’s wishes.
item.dc:creator: Joy Dong
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Hong Kong Golf Club, in the Fanling area of the city, in 2018.

item.title: Suicide Bombing at Pakistan Mosque Kills At Least 44
item.description: The country’s worst attack in months struck the northwest, where the police and military have been targeted, especially in areas straddling the border with Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: Salman Masood
item.media:description: Rescue workers treated a person wounded in the attack on Monday at a mosque frequented by police officers in Peshawar, Pakistan.

item.title: Gandhi’s Life in Photos, 75 Years After His Assassination
item.description: Known as the father of Indian independence, his concept of nonviolent resistance to fight injustice has inspired political movements around the world.
item.dc:creator: Alex Travelli and Matej Leskovsek
item.media:description: Mohandas K. Gandhi, affectionately called “Bapu,” or father, was killed on Jan. 30, 1948. He is still revered by many, his name a byword for a certain kind of virtue and action.

item.title: Israel Launched Drone Attack on Iranian Facility, Officials Say
item.description: While the target’s purpose is unclear, the city of Isfahan is a major center of Iranian missile production, research and development.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, David E. Sanger and Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: West Asia News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: A video capturing what is said to be the moment a drone hit a military factory in Isfahan, Iran.

item.title: Some Wagner Convict Fighters in Ukraine Are Returning to Russia
item.description: Tens of thousands of inmates have joined a mercenary group fighting with the Kremlin’s decimated forces in Ukraine. Some of them are returning to civilian life with military training and, in many cases, battlefield traumas.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Alina Lobzina and Ekaterina Bodyagina
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A poster showing a member of the Russian military near the headquarters of the Wagner private military company in St. Petersburg, Russia.

item.title: ‘Squid Game’ Actor Oh Young-soo Goes on Trial on Sex Crime Charges on Feb. 3
item.description: Oh Young-soo, the actor who portrayed a contestant in the popular Netflix series, is accused of inappropriately touching a South Korean woman in 2017.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:description: Oh Young-soo arriving at a “Squid Game” event in Los Angeles in 2022.

item.title: The Hunt for Nazi-Buried Treasure in a Dutch Village
item.description: The public release of a map from the 1940s has drawn fortune seekers with shovels and metal detectors to a small Dutch village. Not everyone is excited.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.media:description: Annet Waalkens, an adviser at the Dutch National Archives in The Hague, with the file that includes the hand-drawn map by a Nazi soldier from the 1940s.

item.title: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak Fires Nadhim Zahawi, U.K. Conservative Party Chairman
item.description: In trying to bring “integrity” back to Downing Street, Rishi Sunak fired Nadhim Zahawi, the chairman of the governing Conservatives, over his personal tax affairs.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Nadhim Zahawi leaving the Conservative Party offices in London last week.

item.title: The Gin Boom Trying to Change India, One Distillery at a Time
item.description: Local concoctions are challenging the country’s conservative attitude toward alcohol, along with the country’s often stultifying bureaucracy.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Anindito Mukherjee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nao Spirits was one of the first companies to distill, bottle and sell craft gin in Goa, in southern India. At this bottling plant, employees conducted a quality control check.

item.title: Can K-Pop Make the Metaverse Cool?
item.description: In the world’s testing ground for tech, K-pop singers are being spun up out of pixels and doing battle in a virtual universe.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young and Matt Stevens
item.media:credit: Jun Michael Park for The New York Times
item.media:description: A news conference to promote “Girl’s Re:verse” in December. The penguin, a popular mascot called Pengsoo, is one of the judges.

item.title: Ukraine Urges Allies to Speed Up Delivery of Weaponry
item.description: “We have to make time our weapon,” President Volodymyr Zelensky declared as Ukrainians girded for an expected Russian offensive.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes, Alan Yuhas and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen of Denmark during a visit to the city of Mykolaiv on Monday.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: A Bombing in Pakistan
item.description: Also, Israel attacks Iran and the Adani Group fights fraud allegations.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg and Daniel E. Slotnik
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A suicide bomber struck Monday inside a mosque in the city of Peshawar, Pakistan, killing multiple people and wounding scores of worshippers.

item.title: NATO’s Chief Hints That South Korea Should Consider Military Aid to Ukraine
item.description: NATO’s secretary-general, Jens Stoltenberg, urged South Korea to increase its support for Ukraine in the face of Russia’s invasion.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Jens Stoltenberg, NATO’s secretary-general, speaking at the Chey Institute for Advanced Studies in Seoul on Sunday.

item.title: Turkey Raises Fresh Objections to Sweden and Finland’s NATO Bids
item.description: As he faces a tough fight for re-election, President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey has been raising fresh objections to Sweden and Finland’s NATO membership bids.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan speaking in Ankara this month.

item.title: Boris Johnson Claims Putin Threatened to Fire a Missile at Him
item.description: The former British prime minister said the Russian leader made the remark during a phone call in the weeks before Putin’s forces invaded Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Boris Johnson visiting Borodianka, Ukraine, this month.

item.title: How the Migrant Surge Is Playing Out Beyond the Southern U.S.
item.description: How the migrant surge is playing out far from the Southern U.S.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Jeenah Moon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants arriving in New York City by bus from Texas in December.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: A wave of violence in Israel and the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Checking the damage after a fire in a village near Ramallah, in the occupied West Bank.

item.title: As Israelis Grieve, Some Palestinians Exult, and Some Fear What’s Next
item.description: Two Palestinians shot a dozen Israelis, seven fatally, over the weekend. In the aftermath, the attackers’ relatives expressed a mixture of pride and dread.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Afif H. Amireh for The New York Times

item.title: Your Monday Briefing: The Fallout from a Police Beating
item.description: Also, violence is flaring in Israel and the West Bank.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Ahmed Gaber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Times Square on Friday.

item.title: In the Fight Over Gas Stoves, Meet the Industry’s Go-To Scientist
item.description: Longstanding research shows the health dangers of gas-burning ranges. Utilities are turning to Julie Goodman, a toxicologist with a firm whose work raises questions about the science.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: Dr. Goodman in an image from a 2021 video of a community meeting in Massachusetts regarding health concerns related to a fireworks facility.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Battle for Control of Villages Near the Key City of Bakhmut
item.description: The area is a flash point in an offensive that Moscow views as crucial for its goal of seizing the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on their way to the front line on Saturday in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Industry Gatekeepers
item.description: One company controls a wide swath of the concert industry, and lawmakers say music fans are paying the price.
item.dc:creator: Ashley Wu
item.media:description: A small number of people demonstrated outside the Senate office building during the hearing on Tuesday, some holding signs referencing the Taylor Swift ticket debacle.

item.title: Palestinian Man Fatally Shot as Violence Continues in Israel
item.description: Tensions and violence have gripped the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Jerusalem for days after an Israeli military raid on Thursday killed 10 people.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: A Palestinian man checking damage on Sunday after a fire overnight in a village near Ramallah, in the occupied West Bank.

item.title: Bus Plunge in Pakistan Kills at Least 40
item.description: The vehicle plunged down a ravine while traveling more than 300 miles from Quetta to the port city of Karachi.
item.dc:creator: Tiffany May
item.media:description: The wreckage of a passenger bus that plunged down a ravine on Sunday on the road from Quetta to Karachi, Pakistan.

item.title: Iran Says It Thwarted a Drone Attack on a Munitions Facility
item.description: The government did not say who was behind the attempted attack, but some Telegram channels affiliated with Iran’s Revolutionary Guards pointed the finger at Israel.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Isfahan, a city in central Iran that was the target of a drone strike Saturday.

item.title: Hundreds Gather to Memorialize Renowned African Human Rights Lawyer
item.description: Thulani Maseko, who had pushed for years to end Africa’s last absolute monarchy, in Eswatini, formerly Swaziland, was killed in front of his wife and two young children.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: Thulani Maseko in 2018 in Eswatini. He was killed a week ago.

item.title: Netherlands and Japan Said to Join U.S. in Curbing China’s Access to Chip Tech
item.description: A new agreement is expected to expand the reach of U.S. technology restrictions on China issued last year.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.media:description: Workers at ASML in Veldhoven, Netherlands in 2018. The company’s products include advanced semiconductor printing machines.

item.title: Czech Republic Elects Petr Pavel President Over Andrej Babis
item.description: Petr Pavel, a political novice, defeated Andrej Babis, a populist business tycoon and former prime minister, in the first of several important European elections this year.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Petr Pavel, the winner of the runoff vote in the Czech Republic’s presidential election, arriving on Saturday at his campaign headquarters in Prague.

item.title: Amid Spasm of Violence, Israel’s Far-Right Government Raises Risk of Escalation
item.description: Israel and the West Bank were gripped by violence this week. Its roots predate Israel’s new far-right government, but the government’s ministers and goals are fueling tensions.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Residents on Saturday mourned the killing of seven people the night before by a Palestinian gunman outside a synagogue in East Jerusalem.

item.title: British Airline, Flybe, Collapses a Second Time
item.description: Flybe, once the largest independent regional airline in Europe, canceled all flights on Saturday. A new owner failed to save the carrier, which was already struggling when the pandemic hit.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: The British airline Flybe abruptly shut down on Saturday, stranding about 2,500 passengers.

item.title: Fighting Rages in Eastern Ukraine Over Critical Supply Routes
item.description: While the heaviest fighting is still around the city of Bakhmut, in recent days Russian forces have stepped up assaults on a strategic town farther to the south.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers on their way to the front line on Saturday in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Tiny Radioactive Capsule Missing in Australia
item.description: The device, part of a sensor used in mining, is believed to have fallen off the back of a truck while in transit.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: A reservoir at Rio Tinto mines last year. The missing capsule came from a Rio Tinto mine.

item.title: 2 Israelis Injured in Jerusalem Attack, Hours After a Nearby Mass Shooting
item.description: Two Israelis were shot and injured on Saturday in East Jerusalem, the day after an attack outside a synagogue elsewhere in the city killed seven people.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: A person on a stretcher at what was believed to be the scene of the shooting on Saturday. The attack occurred in a mainly Palestinian district of East Jerusalem, not far from some of the holiest sites in the Old City.

item.title: Police Beating in Memphis
item.description: Americans once again protested after another recorded instance of police brutality.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:description: Surveillance video released by the Memphis Police Department shows officers kicking and punching Tyre Nichols, a 29-year-old Black man, and beating him with a baton at one point while he shows no signs of resisting or fighting back.

item.title: What Happened to Canada’s Cold War Relics?
item.description: Few of the sites built to protect Canadians from a radioactive cloud of destruction have been preserved.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: The view from inside the vault in the Diefenbunker where the Bank of Canada’s gold reserves would be stored during a nuclear war.

item.title: Kharkiv Got Some Breathing Space, but Still Doesn’t Breathe Easily
item.description: For the past four months, residents have slowly trickled back into the reclaimed city. But signs of the conflict — and the chance that it might return — are everywhere.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Lynsey Addario
item.media:description: A resident towing water from a school back to his apartment this month in the battered neighborhood of Saltivka, in Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: To Fix Its Problems in Ukraine, Russia Turns to the Architect of the War
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin is on his third overall commander in Ukraine. But his military’s fundamental issues have not been addressed, Western officials say.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Gen. Valery V. Gerasimov, his third war commander in months.

item.title: Move Over, Pablo Neruda. Young Chileans Have a New Favorite Poet.
item.description: Gabriela Mistral, the first Latin American to win a Nobel Prize for literature, was long considered staid. A new generation is reclaiming her as an anti-establishment icon.
item.dc:creator: Ana Lankes
item.category: A Queer Mother for the Nation: The State and Gabriela Mistral (Book)
item.media:description: A contemporary mural in Santiago turns the late Chilean poet Gabriela Mistral into a countercultural icon.

item.title: New Zealand’s Largest City Grapples With Aftermath of Devastating Floods
item.description: At least three people were killed in the flooding in Auckland that forced hundreds of people from their homes and shut down the city’s airport, which was submerged.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A flooded construction site in Auckland, New Zealand, on Saturday, the morning after the worst downpour since record-keeping began for the city.

item.title: Russia Outlaws a News Site and a Rights Group, Stifling Critical Voices
item.description: The Kremlin stepped up efforts to banish independent sources of news. Prosecutors labeled Meduza, a popular news site, “undesirable,” so anyone who aids or promotes it can be prosecuted.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: A photograph released by Russian state media showing President Vladimir V. Putin attending a meeting of the Russian Security Council via video conference on Friday.

item.title: Tanks Alone Won’t Turn the Tide of the War in Ukraine
item.description: The United States will have to step up its training program to ensure the Ukrainian military can use all the Western-provided equipment effectively.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Eric Schmitt
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: The advanced tanks Washington has promised to Ukraine send important signals to both Kyiv and Moscow about continued American support.

item.title: Expert Panel Votes for Stricter Rules on Risky Virus Research
item.description: The White House will decide whether to adopt the panel’s recommendations on so-called gain of function experiments.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller and Carl Zimmer
item.category: National Science Advisory Board for Biosecurity
item.media:description: Proponents of stronger oversight applauded the recommendations, while critics were wary of an oversight system that they worried would stymie experiments with potential public health benefits.

item.title: China’s Oil and Gas Use Fell in 2022 for First Time in Decades
item.description: Pandemic lockdowns curbed Chinese energy demand, but the International Energy Agency expects a rebound this year.
item.dc:creator: Clifford Krauss
item.media:description: A tanker along the Chinese coast this month. China’s oil and gas consumption declined in 2022 for the first time in 40 years, the International Energy Agency says.

item.title: Eurostar, Symbol of a Connected Europe, Is Plagued by Brexit Hurdles
item.description: The high-speed train service under the English Channel is leaving many seats unfilled, rather than risk delays caused by more rigorous passport checks for Britons.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: On some trains that would normally carry up to 900 riders, the company is limiting capacity to about 600.

item.title: At Least 7 Killed in Shooting at a Jerusalem Synagogue
item.description: The police said a 21-year-old man with a handgun shot people on the street at close range, then fled and was killed himself by police gunfire.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Jonathan Rosen
item.media:description: Israeli emergency service personnel and security forces near the site of the attack on Friday.

item.title: Alan Cumming Returns British Honor Over ‘Toxicity of Empire’
item.description: The Scottish actor Alan Cumming said that he returned his Order of the British Empire, or O.B.E., in protest of the role of the monarchy and empire. He’s not the first celebrity to do so.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.category: Elizabeth II, Queen of Great Britain
item.media:description: Alan Cumming said that discussions about the legacy of the British monarchy that followed Queen Elizabeth II’s death “really opened my eyes.”

item.title: Álvaro Colom, Guatemalan President Who Fought for the Indigenous, Dies at 71
item.description: He expanded access to education and health care in Indigenous villages and provided aid to the poor in a country scarred by deep inequalities and decades of civil war.
item.dc:creator: Elisabeth Malkin
item.media:description: Álvaro Colom, after being sworn in as president of Guatemala in 2008. He tried to ameliorate the country’s deep economic divides.

item.title: AP Retreats From ‘the French’ Stylebook Guidance
item.description: The Associated Press offends French sensibilities and retreats from a piece of descriptive advice.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: The cafe scene in Paris.

item.title: Gunman Attacks Azerbaijan Embassy in Tehran, Killing the Head of Security
item.description: Iranian officials blamed the assault, which also wounded two guards, on “personal motivations,” while the Azerbaijani authorities called it a “terrorist attack.” A suspect is in custody.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Police officers outside the Azerbaijani Embassy in Tehran on Friday. Iran and Azerbaijan have a strained diplomatic relationship.

item.title: ‘We Have to Come Here to Be Seen’: Protesters Descend on Lima
item.description: Peru’s unrest continues unabated as the demonstrations move to the country’s capital and the government doubles down on portraying demonstrators as pawns for nefarious interests.
item.dc:creator: Mitra Taj and Marco Garro
item.media:credit: Marco Garro for The New York Times

item.title: New Zealand Floods: Rain and Flooding Batters Auckland
item.description: Auckland declared a local state of emergency as a devastating deluge prompted chaotic scenes, evacuations and power outages. “Steep roads just became rivers of water,” one resident said.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Hayden Woodward/New Zealand Herald, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Emergency workers and a resident wading through floodwaters in Auckland, New Zealand, on Friday.

item.title: Russia says it will switch four occupied Ukrainian regions to Moscow time.
item.description: Russia, which has many time zones, is seeking to integrate the regions after illegally annexing them in September.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Law enforcement officers standing guard during a concert in Moscow in September recognizing the declared annexation of four Ukrainian regions.

item.title: Polar Vortex Drives a Cold Snap in Asia
item.description: An exceptionally cold January has brought the region misery and snarled travel. Experts blame the same arctic system that hit the United States last month.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives and John Yoon
item.media:description: Visitors braving the cold and snow at Gyeongbokgung Palace in Seoul on Thursday.

item.title: Teenage Rapper, Rooted in Mapuche Identity, Roars for Indigenous Rights
item.description: MC Millaray, 16, an emerging music star in Chile, uses her fierce lyrics to convey five centuries of struggles by the country’s largest Indigenous group against European colonizers.
item.dc:creator: John Bartlett and Tomás Munita
item.media:description: MC Millaray, a 16-year-old emerging rap star, wearing traditional Mapuche dress in Santiago, Chile.

item.title: U.S. Officials Overseeing Aid Say Ukrainian Leaders Are Tackling Corruption
item.description: The ouster of several officials has renewed questions about how the Zelensky government is addressing concerns about aid.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, who campaigned for president as a bold corruption fighter, remains committed to that goal, according to U.S. officials.

item.title: Will U.K. Rejection of Scottish Gender Bill Bolster Independence Movement?
item.description: The intervention from London angered Scottish politicians, but it’s not clear that backers of independence can use the issue to their advantage.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: A demonstration for transgender rights outside the government’s office in Edinburgh this month.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: A barrage of Russian missiles across Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Repairing electrical lines that were damaged by a missile in Hlevakha, Ukraine.

item.title: Is Australia Day Approaching a Tipping Point?
item.description: A majority of Australian adults under 35 support changing the date from Jan. 26.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A protest in Sydney on Thursday. For many Aboriginal Australians, Jan. 26 is seen as a day of sorrow and is known as “Survival Day” or “Invasion Day.”
